title: Quiz 6: Other Faecal-Oral Diseases
description: Exploration of Protozoal infections (Amoebiasis, Giardiasis), Viral Hepatitis, and Food Poisoning.

questions.question: Which intestinal protozoa causes offensive, frothy, yellowish diarrhoea and significant malabsorption?
questions.explanation: Giardiasis is characterized by malodorous frothy stools and nutrient malabsorption (fat, B12).

questions.question: What is the causative agent of Amoebiasis, which can cause extra-intestinal disease such as liver abscesses?
questions.explanation: Entamoeba histolytica causes amoebic dysentery and can spread to the liver to form abscesses.

questions.question: Match the Hepatitis virus type with its primary transmission route:
questions.explanation: Hepatitis A and E are 'infectious' (faecal-oral); B, C, and D are 'serum' (blood-borne).
questions.hint: Which one is associated with dirty water?

questions.question: Which stage of viral hepatitis is marked by the appearance of jaundice, dark urine, and pale stools?
questions.explanation: The Icteric phase is defined by the presence of clinical jaundice (icterus).

questions.question: Which of the following symptoms are characteristic of Botulism (Clostridium botulinum poisoning)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Botulism causes neurological symptoms (descending paralysis) but usually no fever.
questions.hint: It affects the cranial nerves first.

questions.question: Amoebic ulcers in the colon are typically described as 'bottle-shaped.'
questions.explanation: E. histolytica causes characteristic flask-shaped or bottle-shaped ulcers in the intestinal mucosa.
questions.hint: Think of the shape of a flask.

questions.question: A group of people fall sick suddenly with severe vomiting and abdominal cramps 2-6 hours after sharing a meal contaminated with pus from a cook's septic finger. What is the likely cause?

richContent.content:
Incident Report

Onset: 4 hours post-meal. Symptoms: Severe cramps, nausea, vomiting. Note: No fever reported among the 10 guests.

questions.explanation: Staphylococcal poisoning has a very rapid onset (1-6 hours) and is caused by pre-formed toxins in food.

questions.question: What is the primary cause of death in patients suffering from Botulism?
questions.explanation: The botulinum toxin causes paralysis of the respiratory muscles.
questions.hint: It affects the ability to breathe.

questions.question: Which immunological marker is the most important for detecting an acute or chronic carrier state of Hepatitis B?
questions.explanation: HBsAg is the primary marker for ongoing Hepatitis B infection.

questions.question: Arrange the 4-F connection sequence from source to mouth:
questions.explanation: Faeces are the source; flies/fingers are the transfer agents; food/fluid is the vehicle; the mouth is the entry.
